module.p: cus glut, too much/many, surfeit is an indeclinable, masculine generic quantity noun, expressing an excessive quantity.

section.p:
On its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid cus. Rachel drank too much.
Tha cus aig Màiri. Mary has too many/much.
Bha a shùilean beag dall mar gum biodh e air cus òl.
His eyes were small and blind as if he had drunk too much. td. 51
A bheil cus ann an cuid de na roinnean?
Are there too many in some of the departments? td. 206

With a genitive modifier –
Dh’òl Raonaid cus uisge. Rachel drank too much water.
Tha cus chon aig Màiri. Mary has too many dogs.
“Uill,” ars esan, “tha mi ’n dòchas gun dìochuimhnich thu m’ amaideas. Tha mi dèanamh cus bruidhinn co-dhiùbh.”
“Well,” he said, “I hope that you will forget my stupidity. I am doing too much talking anyway.” td. 53
Ma sgrìobhas tu seo ann an stòraidh, canaidh iad gu bheil thu dèanamh cus feum dhe cho-thuiteamas.
If you write this in a story, they will say that you are making too much use of co-incidence. td. 120
Bha an sgona air at mar gum biodh fada cus sòda-arain innte.
The scone had swollen up as if there were far too much baking soda in it. 159
Tha cus de Ghàidheil ann fhathast a tha a’ dèanamh seo.
There are still too many Gaels who are doing this. td. 206 Note the (perhaps ‘literary’) use of the preposition de here, rather than a simple genitive.

The preposition de with a definite noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid cus den fhìon. Rachel drank too much of the wine.
Tha cus de mo choin aig Màiri. Mary has too many of my dogs.
’S e a beachd gu feum Alba cumail ceum ri ceum ris na dùthchannan eile, gu bheil fada cus de na dathan bàna, ris an abrar pastels anns a’ chlò.
It is her opinion that Scotland must keep up with the other countries, that there are far too many of the pale colours that are called pastels in the tweed. td. 256

With a prepositional pronoun –
Dh’òl Raonaid cus dheth. Rachel drank too much of it.
Tha cus dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has too many of them.
Tha cus dhiubh ann am Beurla.
Too many of them are in English. td. 206
